awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Affordable Thermo-Responsive Cell Culture Supports for Damage-Free Cell Harvesting
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to reduce production costs of high-quality stem and primary cells for regenerative medicine (RM), consequently reducing medical expenses and improving the quality of life for individuals. RM has a projected global market of $67.6 billion by 2020, and is capable of repairing, replacing and regenerating tissues and organs that are affected by disease/disorder, age, or injury. The common cell harvesting methods cause severe damage to cells, especially primary cells and stem cells. Our technology allows harvesting damage free cells, i.e., retaining essential cell functionalities and characteristics, which are superior for RM. Damage free cells will also enhance basic life science research by obtaining more clinical relevant results that cannot be achieved by using cell lines or damaged cells. While there is one commercially available thermo-responsive product being used to reduce cell damages during harvesting, it is too expensive to be adopted widely. Our technology is low cost, scalable, reproducible, and serves large growing markets. Through this project, we will identify key markets for adoption, correctly define the key product attributes, and understand scaling requirements, hence providing a source of high-quality stem and primary cells for critical medical research and applications.

This I-Corps project will validate market potentials of applying thermo-responsive supports for damage free and chemical free cell harvesting, which is crucial for cell based regenerative medicine and basic life science research. Our technology for generating thermo-responsive supports employs a cost-effective and simple process that involves only 3 steps: blending, casting and thermal annealing of a thermo-responsive polymer and a network forming silane. During annealing, the silane molecules anchor to the surface while simultaneously forming networks to entrap polymer chains. Other reported thermo-responsive surfaces generally are prepared by using non-easily accessible electron beam irradiation or plasma polymerization to deposit a thermo-responsive layer, or painstakingly grow the thermo-responsive polymer on a surface. Also, as compared to the commercial product, our technology allows enhanced cell attachment and growth, and accelerated cell detachment upon cooling, thus avoiding cell damage. Therefore, our technology, described in research papers and patent protected, provides better platforms for commercial expansion of stem and primary cells and for basic research. In addition, our technology, with small scale samples, has been validated by another research group for a variety of applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The Project (I-Corps: Affordable Thermo-Responsive Cell Culture Supports for Damage-Free Cell Harvesting) aims at validating the commercial potentials of thermoresponsive cell culture supports, especially in regenerative medicine. Our team (Team # 1274 I.C.X. ? Intelligent Cell Expansion) participated in the 2018 Summer Bay Area I-Corps cohort (7 weeks) and was the recipient of the ?Spirit of I-CorpsTM Award? for our hard work, discipline and intellectual honesty.  The insight gained from conducting first ~ 30 customer interviews led us to pivot from our initial plan of making thermoresponsive inserts to creating thermoresponsive liners for bioreactors used for bioprocessing.  Additional interviews (~ 70) during the cohort validated that the need of bioreactors and the need in improving current bioreactor design. These additional interviews also informed the necessity for ductile and commonly inexpensive materials, such as polymers, instead of rigid glass, for bioreactors. During the project period following the I-Corps cohort, we focused on prototype building of polymeric and flexible liners for bioreactors. Due to the use of polymeric supports, we also explored other thermoresponsive polymers, instead of our initially proposed poly(N-isopropyl acrylamide), which requires a high processing temperature. In addition, we continued our customer discovery (~ 70 more interviews), which pointed us to a new potential customer segment in membrane separation industry. Our prototype work has validated the feasibility of fabricating thermo-responsive sheets made of flexible silicone elastomer and natural rubber/cellulose composites at small scale. However, scaling up has proven to be challenging. Unfortunately, we have not been able to produce sufficient quantity of cells using these flexible liners, and occasionally, we have encountered contamination issues. Nevertheless, participating in this I-Corps Team program has taught us the importance of meeting the customer needs with our technology.

This I-Corps team?s project provided excellent opportunities for the two Entrepreneurial Leads (ELs), one was an undergraduate student (Eric T. Brink) in his senior year of study, who participated in the cohort and contributed to the initial prototype design, the other was a graduate student (Elham Malekzadeh) who focused on prototype building and continued interviewing customers during the later project period. In addition to the basic skills in entrepreneurship, both ELs have gained other critical skills (e.g., time management, oral presentation, interviewing and listening to customers, handling criticisms/pressure/rejections, and networking professionally) that would be essential for the success of their future career. The project also provided PI an opportunity for her professional development. She has learned how to better apply her experience and skills in solving technological problems that address customer needs, to listen more to students when they have problems, and to be more open-minded. In courses that deal with a real world problem or a project design, she incorporates what she has learned from the I-Corps program by encouraging and assisting students in determining customer needs before they propose a solution or build a prototype.


Last Modified: 09/27/2021
Modified by: Bi-Min Z Newby
